segments.text: Joseph met her about a year later.
As soon as he entered the room, he noticed her above the heads of the lively crowd, mostly actors and artists gathered to celebrate a premiere at Hamatate.
She stood to the side, a slight smile on her lips, her eyes sad.
What drew him to her was the contrast between her being a very young and beautiful woman and the white streak at the front of her hair.
He started moving towards her, picking up two glasses of wine along the way, one for him and one for her.
Being a man well versed in women's ways, he approached her and offered her a glass.
She took it from his hand and thanked him with that smile, seemingly detached from her surroundings.
Hello, my name is Joseph and I must paint you.
He declared without preamble.
She smiled gently but reservedly.
Well, you don't really have to.
No, you don't understand," he replied seriously.
I really, really must.
All right, she smiled at his childish tone.
We'll see.
Maybe someday.
One of the actors approached her.
Lusinka, he asked, everything all right?
Do you need anything?
Since Abraham had been murdered in a terror attack, everyone treated her with kid gloves.
She designed costumes for their plays and did some office work at the theater.
There she met him and a great love ignited between them.
They were married only two weeks when Abraham was murdered in that planned attack by Arab rioters from Jaffa.
Her close friends surrounded her and she forced herself to continue living mainly for her daughter.
Now she looked from the side at this handsome man who must paint her and smiled to herself sadly.
After the disaster, she distanced herself a bit from the chaos and only occasionally forced herself to attend events with her friends.
trying to share in their joy even slightly and regain some of her lost zest for life.
As she turned around, she saw him walking toward her again.
So, what do you say?
Can we arrange for tomorrow?
What could it hurt, she thought to herself?
At worst, I'll end up with a poor tainting.
I taint tomorrow," she hesitated.
We'll see, maybe next week.
All right, but know that I will find you," he said in a disappointed tone.
More than a month passed before they met again, purely by chance.
She was sitting with a friend at the end of a workday at Cafe Mint's near the theater, and he arrived there and went straight to her.
Finally, I've been running around everywhere looking for you for weeks.
There's no escaping it.
You're sitting down quietly now and letting me paint you.
He pulled out a sketchbook from under his arm and a simple pencil from his pocket, brought a chair closer to her, and immediately started drawing.
A short time later, the friend got up to leave.
Neither Joseph nor Lucy paid any attention to it.
They were both already seriously engrossed in the project.
He didn't utter a word and she didn't move.
Slowly, the drawing began to take shape, and she grew curious to see the result.
At times he would stop, looking deeply into her eyes as if trying to peer into her soul, and she watched his confident hand move the pencil across the paper.
Who is he?
What does he do besides paint?
After all, he needs to make a living somehow, she wondered.
Joseph looked at her with deep seriousness.
As the drawing became her portrait, he realized she had completely captured his heart.
What is it about this mysterious woman whose eyes are so wise and convey such great sorrow that intrigues him more and more?
They sat like that for a long time, quietly and without moving, as she surrendered completely to both his movements and his penetrating gaze.
Suddenly, a large vehicle stopped near the curb next to them.
A pickup truck with particularly high wheels.
A burly man leaned against the window and called to Joseph.
Da Vinci, come on, we need to work too.
He raised his head from the sketchpad.
Almost done, he turned to her with an apologetic expression.
Give me your address, and I'll bring you the drawing at home."
She hesitated for just a moment and gait in her address.
Joseph closed the sketchpad, tucked the pencil back into his pocket, waved goodbye and left.
How strange!
She thought to herself.
It had already been a year since she had looked at anyone or let anyone get close to her.
This was the first time something stirred inside her, for she had followed his every move, seen every muscle in his face twitch and every expression as he concentrated.
Above all, she was moved by the seriousness he possessed while drawing.
The cafe owner approached her.
Did you see those guys from the massage, the cars they drive?
So that's what he does.
Not just painting.
Three days later, late in the evening, she heard a gentle knock on the door.
He stood in front of her with a triumphant boyish smile and said, Look.
He pulled out the sketch pad and showed her.
She was speechless.
With eyes wide open, she looked at the drawing, at Joseph, and back at the drawing, and tears welled up in her eyes.
With his simple pencil, he had managed to express all of her, with her pain and sadness.
So much emotion poured into this drawing.
Such talent.
In an instant, she understood that only someone in love could draw like that.
